issues.description: The problem statement's UML diagram specifies that the StockIngredient constructor should take three parameters (String, int, int), but the template repository implements it with four parameters (String, int, int, boolean). This discrepancy creates confusion for students, as they are instructed to implement according to the diagram, yet the provided template code has an extra parameter that does not align with the intended design, potentially leading them to question the correctness of their implementation or the template.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the template repository's StockIngredient constructor to match the UML diagram by changing it to take only three parameters (String name, int price, int quantity), ensuring consistency with the problem statement and allowing students to implement without confusion.

issues.description: The problem statement refers to ingredient names in lowercase (e.g., 'bacon'), while the code in both the template and solution repositories uses title case (e.g., 'Bacon'). This discrepancy in string casing for the same conceptual entities (ingredient names) could lead to case-sensitive matching issues in Java, causing confusion for students when mapping requirements to implementation, as string comparisons are case-sensitive.
issues.suggested_fix: Standardize the casing of ingredient names across all artifacts to use title case (e.g., 'Bacon') as implemented in the code, and update the problem statement examples to match this for consistent conceptual mapping.
